The rule of the second type is that the prohibited act is other than what the prohibition was attributed to, so it [the act] is good (Hasan) in itself, ugly due to another factor (li-ghayrihi). The doer is committing Haram due to the other factor, not due to the act itself.
Based on this, our companions said: Prohibition regarding legal dispositions implies their establishment (Taqrir). By that, it is meant that the disposition after the prohibition remains legitimate as it was. Because if it did not remain legitimate, the servant would be incapable of acquiring the legitimate act; in that case, it would be a prohibition addressed to the incapable, and that is impossible from the Lawgiver.

Discussion: Prohibition of Sensory and Legal Acts
By this, it differs from sensory acts, because if their essence were ugly, that would not lead to prohibiting the incapable [since they are physical acts, not legal constructs].
Because of this description, the Day of Sacrifice and all forms of legal dispositions are not rendered incapacitated despite the arrival of prohibition regarding them.
Branching from this is the ruling of Corrupt Sale (Bay' Fasid), Corrupt Lease (Ijarah Fasidah), the Vow to fast on the Day of Sacrifice, and all forms of legal dispositions despite the arrival of prohibition regarding them.
So we said: The Corrupt Sale imparts ownership upon possession, considering that it is a 'Sale'. And undoing it is obligatory considering that it is Haram due to another factor.
This is contrary to the marriage of polytheist women, the father's wife, another's wife observing Iddah and his wife, marriage to Mahrams (incestuous relations), and marriage without witnesses. This is because the effect of marriage is the lawfulness of the act (sexual access), and the effect of Prohibition is the unlawfulness of the act; combining them is impossible. So the prohibition is carried upon negation [of validity].
As for the effect of Sale, it is the establishment of ownership, and the effect of Prohibition is the unlawfulness of the action (disposal). It is possible to combine them, such that ownership is established and the action is prohibited. Is it not the case that if juice ferments in the ownership of a Muslim, his ownership of it remains, yet the action (drinking/selling) is prohibited?

Based on this, our companions said: If one vows to fast on the Day of Sacrifice [or] the Days of Tashriq, his vow is valid, because it is a vow for a legitimate fast. Likewise, if he vows to pray at disliked times, it is valid, because it is a vow for a legitimate act of worship based on what we mentioned: that Prohibition necessitates the continuation of the disposition as legitimate.
For this reason, we said: If he starts a voluntary prayer (Nafl) at these times, it becomes binding upon him by the commencement. Committing the Haram is not necessary for the necessity of completion; for if he waits until the prayer becomes lawful by the rising of the sun, or its setting, or its decline, he can complete it without dislike.
By this, it differs from the fast of the Day of Eid. If he starts it, it does not become binding upon him according to Abu Hanifa and Muhammad, because the completion cannot be separated from committing the Haram.
From this type is intercourse with a menstruating woman. The prohibition of approaching her is due to the harm (Adha), due to His Almighty's saying: {And they ask you about menstruation. Say, "It is harm, so keep away from wives during menstruation. And do not approach them until they are pure."} [2:222].
For this reason, we said: Rulings are arranged upon this intercourse. Thus, the Ihsan (legal status of being married) of the one having intercourse is established by it, and the woman becomes lawful for the first husband [if this was a remarriage after three divorces], and the ruling of the Dowry, Iddah, and Maintenance is established by it. If she refused to submit herself due to the dowry, she is considered rebellious (Nashizah) according to them both, so she does not deserve maintenance.
The unlawfulness of the act does not negate the arrangement of legal rulings, like the divorce of a menstruating woman, performing Wudu with usurped waters, hunting with a usurped bow, slaughtering with a usurped knife, praying on usurped land, and selling at the time of the Call to Prayer [on Friday]. Indeed, the ruling is arranged upon these dispositions despite their inclusion of unlawfulness.
Considering this principle, we said regarding His Almighty's saying: {And do not accept for them testimony, ever} [24:4]...

The Twelfth Chapter: Chapter on Defining the Method of [Knowing] the Intent of Texts

...that the Fasiq (sinner) is among the people of testimony. Thus, marriage is contracted by the testimony of Fasiqs. This is because prohibiting the acceptance of testimony is impossible without the [existence of] testimony. Their testimony was only not accepted due to corruption in the performance, not due to the absence of testimony fundamentally. Based on this, Lian (curse oath) is not obligated upon them, because that is the performance of testimony, and there is no performance with a Fasiq.

Discussion: The Method of Knowing the Intent of Texts
Know that there are methods for knowing the intent of texts.
Among them:
1 - If a word is Literal (Haqiqah) for a meaning and Metaphorical (Majaz) for another, the Literal takes precedence.
An example is what our scholars said: The daughter created from the water of Zina (adultery); marrying her is prohibited for the adulterer. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: It is lawful. The correct view is what we said, because she is his daughter literally, so she enters under His Almighty's saying: {Prohibited to you are your mothers and your daughters} [4:23]. Branching from this are the rulings in the two schools regarding the lawfulness of intercourse, the obligation of dowry, the necessity of maintenance, the flow of inheritance, and the guardianship of preventing her from going out and appearing.

2 - Among them is that if one of two interpretations necessitates a specification (Takhsis) in the text while the other does not, the interpretation upon what does not necessitate specification is preferred.
An example is in His Almighty's saying: {Or you have touched (Lamastum) women} [4:43]. If 'Touching' is interpreted as Intercourse...

...the text is acted upon in all forms of its existence. But if it is interpreted as touching with the hand, the text becomes specified (Makhsus) regarding it in many forms. For touching Mahrams (incestuous relatives) and the very young girl does not break Wudu in the soundest of Al-Shafi'i's two views. Branching from this are the rulings in the two schools regarding the permissibility of prayer, touching the Mushaf, entering the mosque, the validity of leading prayer, the necessity of Tayammum when water is lacking, and remembering the touch during prayer.

3 - Among them is that if the text is read with two readings (Qira'at) or narrated with two narrations, acting upon it in a way that implements both aspects is preferred.
An example is in His Almighty's saying: {And your feet (Arjulakum)} [5:6]. It is read with Nasb (accusative) conjoined to the washed parts, and with Khafd (genitive) conjoined to the wiped part. The reading of Khafd was carried upon the state of wearing Khuffs (leather socks), and the reading of Nasb upon the state of not wearing Khuffs. Considering this meaning, some said: The permissibility of wiping [the Khuffs] is established by the Book.
Likewise, His Almighty's saying: {Until they are pure (Yathurna)} [2:222]. It is read with Tashdid (Yattahharna) and Takhfif (Yathurna). The reading of Takhfif is acted upon when her days are ten [maximum menstruation], and the reading of Tashdid when her days are less than ten.
Based on this, our companions said: If the menstrual blood stops at less than ten...

...days, intercourse with the menstruating woman is not permissible until she performs Ghusl (bathes), because the perfection of purity is established by bathing [acting on Tashdid]. But if her blood stops at ten days, intercourse with her is permissible before Ghusl, because absolute purity is established by the cessation of blood [acting on Takhfif].
For this reason, we said: If the menstrual blood stops at ten days at the end of the prayer time, the obligatory prayer of that time becomes binding upon her, even if there does not remain of the time an amount in which she can bathe. But if her blood stops at less than ten days at the end of the prayer time: if there remains of the time an amount in which she can bathe and say the Takbir for prayer, the obligation binds her; otherwise, it does not.

Then we mention methods of weak deductions (Tamassukat) so that this may be an alert to the place of defect in this type.
Among them: Arguing by what was narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, (that he vomited and did not perform Wudu) to prove that vomit does not break Wudu is weak. This is because the trace indicates that vomit does not necessitate Wudu *immediately*, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding it being a nullifier.
Likewise, arguing by His Almighty's saying: {Prohibited to you is dead animals (Al-Maitah)} [5:3] to prove the corruption of water by the death of a fly is weak. This is because the text establishes the prohibition of [eating] the Maitah, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding the spoiling of the water.
Likewise, arguing by his saying, peace be upon him: (Scrape it, then pinch/rub it with water, then wash it with water) to prove that vinegar does not remove impurity is weak. This is because the Report implies the obligation of washing the blood with water, so it is restricted to the case of the presence of blood on the locus, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding the purity of the locus after the removal of blood by vinegar.

Likewise, arguing by his saying, peace be upon him: (In forty sheep, a sheep) to prove the impermissibility of paying the value is weak. This is because it implies the obligation of the sheep, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding the dropping of the obligation by performing the payment of the value.

Discussion: Weak and Corrupt Deductions

Likewise, arguing by His Almighty's saying: {And complete the Hajj and Umrah for Allah} [2:196] to prove the obligation of Umrah initially is weak. This is because the text implies the obligation of completion, and that is only after commencement, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding its obligation initially.
Likewise, arguing by his saying, peace be upon him: (Do not sell one Dirham for two Dirhams, nor one Sa' for two Sa's) to prove that Corrupt Sale does not impart ownership is weak. This is because the text implies the prohibition of the Corrupt Sale, and there is no dispute in that; the dispute is only regarding the establishment of ownership or lack thereof.
Likewise, arguing by his saying, peace be upon him: (Do not fast on these days, for they are days of eating, drinking, and conjugal relations) to prove that a Vow to fast on the Day of Sacrifice is not valid is weak. This is because the text implies the unlawfulness of the act, and there is no dispute regarding it being Haram; the dispute is only regarding the utility of legal rulings despite it being Haram.
The unlawfulness of the act does not negate the arrangement of legal rulings. For if a father impregnates his son's slave girl, it is Haram, yet ownership [of the girl] is established for the father. If one slaughters a sheep with a usurped knife, it is Haram, yet the slaughtered animal becomes Halal. If one washes an impure garment with usurped water, it is Haram, yet the garment becomes pure by it.

And if one has intercourse with a woman in the state of menstruation, it is Haram, yet the Ihsan (legal status of marriage) of the one having intercourse is established by it, and lawfulness for the first husband is established.

The Thirteenth Chapter: Establishing the Particles of Meanings (Huruf al-Ma'ani)

The Waw (And) is for Absolute Collection. It is said that Al-Shafi'i made it for Order (Tartib). Based on this, Order is obligatory in the chapter of Wudu.
Our scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: If he says to his wife, "If I speak to Zayd OR (wa - and) Amr, you are divorced," and he speaks to Amr then Zayd, she is divorced. The meaning of order and comparison is not a condition in it.
If he says: "If you enter this house AND this house, you are divorced," and she enters the second then enters the first, she is divorced.
Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If he says, "If you enter the house, you are divorced," she is divorced immediately? [No], if that implied order, divorce would be ordered by it upon entry, and that would be a suspension (Ta'liq), not an immediate effect (Tanjiz).
The Waw may be for the Circumstantial State (Hal), combining the State (Hal) and the Owner of the State (Dhu al-Hal); in that case, it conveys the meaning of a Condition.
An example is what he said regarding the Authorized Slave (Ma'dhun): If he says to his slave, "Pay me a thousand AND you are free," the payment is a condition for freedom.
Muhammad said in Al-Siyar Al-Kabir: If the Imam says to the disbelievers, "Open the door AND you are safe," they are not safe without opening. If he says to the Harbi (enemy warrior), "Descend AND you are safe," he is not safe without descending.
The Waw is only carried upon the Hal by way of Metaphor (Majaz), so there must be...

...a possibility in the word for that, and the existence of an indication for its establishment. As in the master's saying to his slave: "Pay me a thousand AND you are free." Indeed, freedom is realized at the moment of payment, and the indication for that is established: for the master is not owed money by his slave while slavery exists in him [since the slave and his wealth belong to the master]. Yet, suspension [of freedom] on it is valid, so it is carried upon that.

Discussion on 'Waw' (And) being for absolute conjunction and 'Fa' (Then/So) for immediate succession. If he says, 'You are divorced and you are sick' or '...praying,' she is divorced immediately. Even if he intended suspension (Ta'liq), his intention is valid between him and Allah the Exalted, because the wording, although it bears the meaning of the state (Hal), the apparent meaning is contrary to it; but when it is supported by his intent, it is established [religiously]. If he says, 'Take this thousand as Mudarabah and work with it in cloth,' the work is not restricted to cloth, and the Mudarabah is general, because working in cloth is not suitable as a state (Hal) for taking the thousand as Mudarabah, so the beginning of the speech is not restricted by it. Based on this, Abu Hanifa said: If she says to her husband, '(Divorce me and you have a thousand),' and he divorces her, nothing is owed to him from her, because her saying 'and you have a thousand' does not signify a state of obligation of the thousand upon her, and her saying 'Divorce me' is significant by itself, so acting upon it is not abandoned without proof. This is contrary to his saying, 'Carry this merchandise and you have a dirham,' because the indication of hire (Ijara) prevents acting upon the literal meaning of the word [as a mere gift/offer], and for this reason, it is used in retributions because it follows the condition. Our companions, may Allah have mercy on them, said: If he says, 'I sold this slave to you for a thousand,' and the other says...

...'Then (Fa) he is free,' this is accepted as a sale by implication, and emancipation is established from him following the sale. This is contrary to what if he said, 'And he is free' or 'He is free,' for it would be a rejection of the sale. And if he says to a tailor, 'Look at this cloth, is it sufficient for me as a shirt?' and he looks and says 'Yes,' then the owner of the cloth says, 'Then (Fa) cut it,' and he cuts it, but it turns out not to be sufficient, the tailor is liable. This is because he ordered him to cut following [the confirmation of] sufficiency. This is contrary to what if he said, 'Cut it' or 'And cut it,' and he cuts it, for the tailor would not be liable. If he said, 'I sold this garment to you for ten, then (Fa) cut it,' and he cuts it and says nothing, the sale is complete. If he says, 'If you enter this house, then (Fa) this house, you are divorced,' the condition is entering the second immediately following the entering of the first, connected to it. So if she enters the second first, or last but after a duration, the divorce does not occur.

Discussion that 'Fa' may be used to explain causality ('Illah). And 'Fa' may be for the explanation of the cause. An example is if he says to his slave, 'Pay me a thousand, so (Fa) you are free,' the slave is free immediately even if he does not pay anything. And if he says to a warmonger (Harbi), 'Descend, so (Fa) you are safe,' he is safe even if he does not descend. And in Al-Jami': If he says, 'The matter of my wife is in your hand, so divorce her,' and he divorces her in the session, she is divorced with one irrevocable (Ba'in) divorce, and the second clause is not an appointment of agency for a divorce other than the first; it becomes as if he said, 'Divorce her because her matter is in your hand.' If he said, 'Divorce her, so (Fa) I have made her matter in your hand,' and he divorces her in the session, she is divorced with a revocable divorce. If he said, 'Divorce her and (Wa) I have made her matter in your hand,' and he divorces her in the session, she is divorced with two divorces. Likewise, if he said, 'Divorce her and separate her' or 'Separate her and divorce her,' and he divorces her in the session, two divorces occur. Based on this, our companions said: If a married bondmaid is emancipated, the option (Khiyar) is established for her, whether her husband is a slave or free. This is because his saying, upon him be peace, to Buraydah when she was emancipated, (You owned your vulva, so choose), established the option for her due to her owning her vulva by emancipation. This meaning does not differ between the husband being a slave or free. And from this branches the issue of 'Consideration of divorce is by women'; for the vulva of the bondmaid...

...is the property of the husband [via marriage] and did not leave his ownership by her emancipation. So necessity called for saying that ownership increases by her emancipation, such that ownership in the excess is established for him, and that becomes a cause for the establishment of the option for her. And the increase of ownership of the vulva by her emancipation is the meaning of the issue 'Consideration of divorce is by women.' Thus, the ruling of owning three [divorces] revolves around the emancipation of the wife, not the emancipation of the husband, as is the school of Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him.

Section: 'Thumma' (Then) is for delay. However, according to Abu Hanifa, it indicates delay in wording and ruling. According to them (Abu Yusuf and Muhammad), it indicates delay in ruling [only]. Its explanation is in the case where he says to a woman with whom marriage has not been consummated, 'If you enter the house, then you are divorced, then (Thumma) divorced.' According to him (Abu Hanifa), the first is attached to the entry, and the second occurs immediately, and the third is void. According to them, all are attached to the entry; then upon entry, the sequence appears, so only one occurs. If he said, 'You are divorced, then divorced, then divorced if you enter the house'; according to Abu Hanifa, the first occurs immediately, and the second and third are void. According to them, one occurs upon entry due to what we mentioned. If the woman was consummated with, if he advanced the condition, the first is attached to the entry and two occur immediately according to Abu Hanifa. If he delayed the condition, two occur immediately and the third is attached to the entry. According to them, all are attached to the entry in both sections.

Discussion on 'Bal' (Nay/Rather) being placed to rectify a mistake. Section: 'Bal' is for rectifying a mistake by establishing the second in place of the first. If he says to a woman with whom marriage has not been consummated, 'You are divorced once, no, rather (Bal) two,' one occurs. This is because his saying 'no, rather two' is a retraction from the first by establishing the second in place of the first, and his retraction is not valid [in creating divorce], so the first occurs. Thus, the locus [of divorce] does not remain at his saying 'two.' If she was consummated with, three occur. This is contrary to what if he said, 'I owe Fulan a thousand, no, rather two thousand,' where three thousand is not obligatory according to us. Zufar said: Three thousand is obligatory, because the reality of the word is to rectify the mistake by establishing the second in place of the first, and invalidating the first is not valid from him [in debt], so validating the second while the first remains is obligatory. That is by way of increasing the thousand upon the first thousand. This is contrary to his saying 'You are divorced once, no, rather two,' because this is origination (Insha'), and that [debt] is reporting (Ikhbar). Mistake occurs in reporting, not in origination. So it was possible to validate the wording by rectifying the mistake in acknowledgement, but not in divorce. Even if the divorce was by way of reporting, such as saying, 'I had divorced you yesterday once, no, rather two,' two would occur due to what we mentioned.

Discussion on 'Lakin' (But) being for rectification after negation. Section: 'Lakin' is for rectification after negation, so its requirement is the affirmation of what follows it. As for the negation of what precedes it, it is established by its own evidence. Conjunction with this word is only realized when the speech is consistent. If the speech is consistent, the negation relates to the affirmation that follows it; otherwise, it is a new sentence. An example is what Muhammad mentioned in Al-Jami': If he says, 'I owe Fulan a thousand as a loan,' and Fulan says, 'No, but as usurpation,' the money is binding upon him because the speech is consistent; so it appeared that the negation was regarding the cause, not the money itself. Similarly, if he says, 'I owe Fulan a thousand from the price of this slave,' and Fulan says, 'No, the slave is yours, but I have a thousand against you,' the money is binding upon him. So it appeared that the negation was regarding the cause, not regarding the principal of the money. If he had a slave in his hand and said, 'This belongs to Fulan,' and Fulan said, 'He was never mine, but he belongs to another Fulan': If the speech is connected, the slave belongs to the second acknowledged person because the negation relates to the affirmation. If separated, the slave belongs to the first acknowledged person, and the statement of the acknowledged person becomes a rejection of the acknowledgement.

And if a bondmaid married herself without her master's permission for one hundred dirhams, and the master said, 'I do not authorize the contract for one hundred, but I authorize it for one hundred and fifty,' the contract is void. This is because the speech is not consistent, for negating the authorization and affirming it [the same authorization] regarding the same thing is not realized. So his saying 'but I authorize it' was an affirmation after the rejection of the contract. Similarly, if he said, 'I do not authorize it, but I authorize it if you add fifty to the hundred,' it is an annulment of the marriage due to the lack of possibility of explanation (Bayan), because its condition is consistency, and there is no consistency.

Discussion on 'Aw' (Or) covering one of the mentioned items. Section: 'Aw' is for covering one of the mentioned items. For this reason, if he said, 'This one is free or this one,' it is in the status of his saying 'One of them is free,' such that he has the authority of explanation (Bayan). If he said, 'I appointed [you] to sell this slave, this one or this one,' the agent is for one of them, and the sale is permitted for each one of them. If he sold one of them, then the slave returned to the ownership of the principal, the other does not have the right to sell him. If he said regarding three wives of his, 'This one is divorced or this one and this one,' one of the first two is divorced, and the third is divorced immediately due to her being conjoined to the divorced one of them. The choice belongs to the husband in specifying the divorced one among the [first] two, in the status of if he said 'One of you two is divorced and this one.' Based on this, Zufar said: If he said, 'I will not speak to this one or this one or this one,' it is in the status of his saying 'I will not speak to one of these two and this one.' So he does not break the oath unless he speaks to one of the first two and the third. According to us, if he speaks to the first one alone, he breaks the oath; and if he speaks to one of the others [implying the second or third in a different grouping context, or specifically the second part of the 'or'], he does not break the oath unless he speaks to both. If he said, 'Sell this slave or this one,' he has the right to sell one of them, whichever he wishes. If he entered into paying the dowry by marrying her 'for this or for this'...

...the fair dower (Mahr al-Mithl) is judged according to Abu Hanifa, because the wording covers one of them, and the original requirement is the fair dower, so what resembles it is preferred. Based on this, we said: The Tashahhud is not a pillar in the prayer, because his saying, upon him be peace, (If you said this or did this, your prayer is complete)...

...suspended the completion upon one of them, so each one of them is not a condition. And the sitting is a condition by agreement, so the recitation of the Tashahhud is not a condition. Then, this word in the place of negation necessitates the negation of each one of the mentioned items, such that if he says, 'I will not speak to this one or this one,' he breaks the oath if he speaks to one of them. In affirmation, it covers one of them with the attribute of choice, like their saying 'Take this or that.' And from the necessity of choice is the generality of permission. Allah the Exalted said: {So its expiation is the feeding of ten needy people from the average of that which you feed your families or clothing them or the freeing of a slave}. Discussion: The coming of 'Aw' to cover one of the mentioned items. And 'Aw' may be in the meaning of 'Hatta' (Until/Unless). Allah the Exalted said: {You have no decision in the matter or [unless] He turns to them in forgiveness}. It is said its meaning is 'Until He turns to them.' Our companions said: If he said, 'I will not enter this house or [until] I enter this house,' 'Aw' is in the meaning of 'Hatta,' such that if he enters the first, he does not break the oath; and if he enters the second first, he is absolved in his oath.

And similar to it is if he said, 'I will not part from you or [until] you pay my debt,' it is in the meaning of 'Hatta' you pay my debt. Discussion: 'Hatta' providing the meaning of the limit/end (Ghaya). Section: 'Hatta' is for the limit, like 'Ila' (To). So if what is before it is capable of extension and what is after it is suitable to be a limit for it, the word operates on its literal meaning. An example is what Muhammad said: If he says, 'My slave is free if I do not beat you until Fulan intercedes' or 'until you scream' or 'until you complain before me' or 'until the night enters,' the word operates on its literal meaning, because beating accepts extension through repetition, and the intercession of Fulan and its likes are suitable as a limit for beating. So if he refrained from beating before the limit, he breaks the oath. And if he swore not to part from his debtor until he pays him his debt, and he parted before the payment of the debt, he breaks the oath. If acting upon the literal meaning is impossible due to an impediment like custom—such as if he swore to beat him until he dies or until he kills him—it is interpreted as severe beating considering custom. If the first is not capable of extension and the other is not suitable as a limit, but the first is suitable as a cause and the other as a recompense, it is interpreted as recompense (Jaza').

An example is what Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If he says to another, 'My slave is free if I do not come to you until you give me lunch,' and he comes to him but he [the other] does not give him lunch, he does not break the oath. This is because giving lunch is not suitable as a limit for coming; rather, it is a motive for the excess of coming, and it is suitable as a recompense. So it is interpreted as recompense, thus being in the meaning of the Lam of purpose (Lam Kai). So it became as if he said, 'If I do not come to you a coming whose recompense is giving lunch.' If this is impossible because the latter is not suitable as a recompense for the former, it is interpreted as pure conjunction. An example is what Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If he says, 'My slave is free if I do not come to you until I have lunch with you today' or 'if you do not come to me until you have lunch with me today,' and he came to him but did not have lunch with him on that day, he breaks the oath. That is because since each of the two actions is attributed to a single essence, his action is not suitable to be a recompense for his [own] action. So it is interpreted as pure conjunction, and the aggregate becomes the condition for fulfillment (Birr).

Discussion on 'Ila' (To) being placed for the end of the limit. Section: 'Ila' is for the end of the limit. Then, in some forms, it provides the meaning of extending the ruling, and in some forms, it provides the meaning of dropping [exclusion]. If it provides extension, the limit is not included in the ruling; and if it provides dropping, it is included. An example of the first: 'I bought this place to (Ila) this wall'; the wall is not included in the sale. An example of the second: 'He sold with the condition of option to (Ila) three days.' Similar to it is if he swore 'I will not speak to Fulan to (Ila) a month'; the month is included in the ruling. It has provided the benefit of dropping [i.e., dropping the wash/ruling from beyond the limit by including the limit] here. Based on this, we said: The elbow and the ankle are included under the ruling of washing in the saying of the Exalted {To the elbows}, because the word {Ila} here is for dropping; for were it not for it, the obligation would have encompassed the entire arm. For this reason, we said: The knee is from the Awrah (nakedness), because the word {Ila} in his saying, upon him be peace, (The Awrah of a man is what is below the navel to the knee) provides the benefit of dropping [exclusion of what is beyond], so the knee enters into the ruling. And his word {Ila} may provide the benefit of delaying the ruling to the limit. For this reason we said: If...

...he says to his wife, 'You are divorced to (Ila) a month,' and he has no intention, the divorce does not occur immediately according to us, contrary to Zufar. This is because mentioning the month is suitable for extending the ruling and dropping [it from the immediate time] legally, and divorce accepts delay by suspension, so it is interpreted as such.

Discussion on the word 'Ala' (Upon) being for obligation and 'Fi' (In) for containment. Section: The word 'Ala' is for obligation. Its origin is to provide the meaning of superiority and elevation. For this reason, if he said, 'Upon me (Li 'alayya) is a thousand for Fulan,' it is interpreted as debt, contrary to if he said 'I have (Indi)' or 'With me (Ma'i)' or 'Before me (Qibali).' Based on this, he said in Al-Siyar Al-Kabir: If the head of the fortress said, 'Grant me safety upon (Ala) ten of the people of the fortress,' and we did so, the ten are other than him, and the option of specification is his. If he said, 'Grant me safety and ten' or 'So ten' or 'Then ten,' and we did so, it is likewise [other than him], and the option of specification belongs to the [granter of] safety. 'Ala' may be in the meaning of 'Ba' (By/For) metaphorically, such that if he said, 'I sold you this upon (Ala) a thousand,' 'Ala' is in the meaning of 'Ba' due to the existence of the indication of exchange. And 'Ala' may be in the meaning of the condition. Allah the Exalted said: {They pledge allegiance to you upon [the condition] that they will not associate anything with Allah}. For this reason, Abu Hanifa said: If she says to her husband, 'Divorce me three times upon (Ala) a thousand,' and he divorces her once, the money is not obligatory, because the word here provides the meaning of the condition, so the three becomes a condition for the obligation of the money.

Discussion on 'Fi' (In) providing the meaning of containment. Section: The word 'Fi' is for containment. Considering this principle, our companions said: If he said, 'I usurped a garment in (Fi) a handkerchief' or 'dates in a basket (Qawsarah),' he is liable for both of them. Then, this word is used for time, place, and action. As for if it is used for time, such as saying 'You are divorced in (Fi) tomorrow': Abu Yusuf and Muhammad said the omission or manifestation of it ['in'] are equal, such that if he said 'You are divorced in tomorrow,' it is in the status of his saying 'You are divorced tomorrow'; the divorce occurs as the dawn breaks in both cases. Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, held that if it is omitted, the divorce occurs as the dawn breaks. But if it is manifested [included], the meaning is the occurrence of divorce in a part of tomorrow by way of indefiniteness; so were it not for the existence of intention, the divorce would occur at the first part due to the lack of a competitor for it. And if he intended the end of the day, his intention is valid. An example of that is in the saying of a man, 'If you fast the month, then you are such-and-such'; it applies to the fasting of the [whole] month. But if he said, 'If you fast in the month, then you are such-and-such,' this applies to withholding for an hour in the month.

As for regarding Place: Like his saying "You are divorced in the house (fi al-dar)" and "in Mecca"; this is a divorce in an absolute sense in all places.
Considering the meaning of Adverbiality (Zarfiyyah), we said: If he swears regarding an action and attributes it to a time or place; if the action is of what is completed by the agent, the presence of the agent in that time or place is conditioned. And if the action extends to a locus (mahall), the presence of the locus in that time and place is conditioned, because the action is realized by its effect, and its effect is in the locus.

Discussion: The Function of the word "Fi" (In) for the meaning of Adverbiality.
Muhammad said in Al-Jami' Al-Kabir: If he says, "If I insult you IN the mosque, then such-and-such [penalty/divorce]," then he insults him while he [the insulter] is in the mosque and the insulted is outside the mosque, he violates the oath. But if the insulter was outside the mosque and the insulted was inside the mosque, he does not violate it.
And if he says, "If I hit you or wound you IN the mosque, then such-and-such," it is conditioned that the one hit and wounded be inside the mosque, and it is not conditioned that the hitter and wounder be inside it.
If he says, "If I kill you IN Thursday, then such-and-such," and he wounds him before Thursday but he dies on Thursday, he violates the oath. But if he wounds him on Thursday and he dies on Friday, he does not violate it.
If the word [Fi] enters upon the action, it conveys the meaning of a Condition.
Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If he says, "You are divorced IN (Fi) your entering the house," it is in the meaning of a condition, so divorce does not occur before entering the house.
If he says, "You are divorced IN your menstruation": if she is currently in menstruation, the divorce occurs immediately. Otherwise, the divorce is attached to [the occurrence of] menstruation.

In Al-Jami': If he says, "You are divorced IN the coming of a day," she is not divorced until dawn breaks. If he says, "IN the passing of a day": if that was at night, the divorce occurs at sunset the next day due to the fulfillment of the condition. And if it was during the day, she is divorced when that same hour comes the next day.
In Al-Ziyadat: If he says, "You are divorced IN the will of Allah Almighty" or "IN the wish of Allah Almighty," that is in the meaning of a condition, so she is not divorced.

Discussion: The Function of the Particle "Ba" for Attachment (Ilsaq).

Chapter: The particle "Ba" is for Attachment in linguistic usage. For this reason, it accompanies prices (Athman).
The verification of this is that the Sold Item (Mabi') is the principal (Asl) in the sale, and the Price (Thaman) is a condition in it. For this reason, the destruction of the Sold Item necessitates the cancellation of the sale, unlike the destruction of the Price.
Since this is established, we say: The principle is that the follower (Tabi') is attached to the principal, not that the principal is attached to the follower. So if the particle "Ba" enters upon the counter-value in the chapter of Sale, it indicates that it is a follower attached to the principal, so it is not the Sold Item, thus it is the Price.
Based on this, we said: If he says, "I sold you this slave FOR (Bi) a Kurr of wheat" and describes it, the slave is the Sold Item and the Kurr is the Price, so substitution [of the Kurr] is permissible before possession.
But if he says, "I sold you a Kurr of wheat" and describes it "FOR (Bi) this slave," the slave is the Price and the Kurr is the Sold Item, and the contract is Salam (advance payment), which is not valid unless deferred.
Our scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: If he says to his slave, "If you inform me OF (Bi) the arrival of So-and-so, you are free," that is contingent upon truthful information, so that the information is attached to the arrival.

So if he informs falsely, he is not set free. But if he says, "If you inform me THAT So-and-so arrived, you are free," that is contingent upon absolute information [speech], so even if he informs him falsely, he is set free.
If he says to his wife, "If you leave the house EXCEPT WITH (Bi) my permission, you are such-and-such," she needs permission every time. Since the exception is an exit attached to permission. So if she leaves a second time without permission, she is divorced.
But if he says, "If you leave the house UNLESS I give you permission," that applies to permission once. So even if she leaves another time without permission, she is not divorced.
In Al-Ziyadat: If he says, "You are divorced BY (Bi) the will of Allah Almighty" or "BY the wish of Allah Almighty" or "BY His command," she is not divorced.

The Fourteenth Chapter: Clarification of Confirmation (Taqrir) and Clarification of Explanation (Tafsir).

Chapter on Types of Clarification (Bayan)
Clarification is of seven types: Clarification of Confirmation (Taqrir), Clarification of Explanation (Tafsir), Clarification of Change (Taghyir), Clarification of Necessity (Darurah), Clarification of State (Hal), Clarification of Conjunction (Atf), and Clarification of Substitution (Tabdil).

As for the First (Taqrir), it is when the meaning of the word is apparent but bears the possibility of another meaning, so he clarifies the intended meaning with what is apparent. Thus, the ruling of the apparent is confirmed by his clarification.
An example is if he says: "I owe So-and-so a Qafiz of wheat, of the town's Qafiz" or "A thousand, of the town's currency." This is a Clarification of Confirmation, because the absolute word was carried upon the town's Qafiz and its currency, with the possibility that another was intended. So when he clarified that, he confirmed it with his clarification.
Likewise, if he says: "I have a thousand for So-and-so as a deposit (Wadi'ah)." The word "I have" (Indi) by its absoluteness implies Trust (Amanah), with the possibility that another meaning was intended. So when he said "deposit," he confirmed the ruling of the apparent with his clarification.

Chapter: As for Clarification of Explanation (Tafsir), it is when the intended meaning of the word is not revealed, so he reveals it with his clarification.
An example is if he says: "I owe So-and-so a 'Thing' (Shay')," then he explains the 'Thing' as a garment. Or he says: "I owe ten Dirhams 'and some' (wa nayyif)," then he explains the 'some'...

...or he says: "I owe Dirhams," and explains them as ten, for example.
The rule of these two types of clarification is that it is valid whether connected (Mawsul) or separated (Mafsul).

Discussion: Clarification of Change (Taghyir).

Chapter: As for Clarification of Change, it is when the meaning of his speech is changed by his clarification. Its counterpart is Suspension (Ta'liq) and Exception (Istithna').
The jurists differed regarding these two sections.
Our companions said: That which is suspended on a condition is a cause (Sabab) at the existence of the condition, not before it.
Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The suspension is a cause immediately, except that the absence of the condition is an impediment (Mani') to its ruling.
The benefit of the disagreement appears in the case where he says to a strange woman: "If I marry you, you are divorced," or to another's slave: "If I own you, you are free."
The suspension is void according to him [Al-Shafi'i], because the rule of suspension is the contracting of the beginning of the speech as a cause (Illah). But Divorce and Manumission here did not contract as a cause due to their lack of attribution to a [valid] locus (Mahall). So the rule of suspension is void, thus the suspension is not valid.
According to us, the suspension is valid. So if he marries her, divorce occurs. This is because his speech contracts as a cause only at the existence of the condition, and ownership is established at the existence of the condition, so the suspension is valid.
For this reason, we said: The condition for the validity of suspension for occurrence in a case of...

...non-ownership is that it be attributed to ownership or to the cause of ownership. So if he says to a strange woman, "If you enter the house, you are divorced," then he marries her and the condition is met, divorce does not occur.

Likewise, the financial capability (Tawl) of [marrying] a free woman prevents the permissibility of marrying a slave girl according to him [Al-Shafi'i], because the Book suspended the marriage of a slave girl on the absence of Tawl. So when Tawl exists, the condition is absent, and the absence of the condition is an impediment to the ruling according to him.
According to us, since the absence of the condition is not an impediment to the ruling, it is permissible for the ruling to be established by its evidence. So marrying a slave girl is permissible [even with Tawl], and maintenance is obligatory due to general texts.

Likewise, Al-Shafi'i said: There is no maintenance for the thrice-divorced woman (Mabtutah) unless she is pregnant, because the Book suspended spending on pregnancy, due to His Almighty's saying: {And if they should be pregnant, then spend on them until they give birth} [65:6]. So when pregnancy is absent, the condition is absent, and the absence of the condition is an impediment to the ruling according to him.
According to us, since the absence of the condition is not an impediment to the ruling, it is permissible for the ruling to be established by its evidence. So maintenance is obligatory due to general texts.

From the followers of this type is arranging a ruling on a noun described by an adjective. For this is in the status of suspending the ruling on that description according to him.
Based on this, Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: Marrying a kitabi (People of the Book) slave girl is not permissible, because the Text arranged the ruling on a believing slave girl, due to His Almighty's saying: {From your believing girls} [4:25]. So it is restricted to the believer, thus the ruling is prevented when the description is absent. So marrying a kitabi slave girl is not permissible.
And among the forms of Clarification of Change is Exception (Istithna').

Discussion on Exception (Istithna') being a form of Explanation of Change. Our companions went to the view that Exception is speaking about the remainder after the exclusion, as if he did not speak except about what remained. According to him [the opponent], the beginning of the speech is established as a cause for the obligation of the whole, but the Exception prevents it from operating, in the status of the absence of a condition in the chapter of suspension. An example of this is in his saying, peace be upon him: (Do not sell food for food except like for like). According to Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, the beginning of the speech is established as a cause for the prohibition of selling food for food absolutely, and the form of equality exited from this totality by the Exception, so the remainder remained under the ruling of the beginning. The result of this is the prohibition of selling a handful of food for two handfuls of it. According to us, the sale of a handful does not enter under the Text, because the intended meaning of the prohibited [act] is restricted to a form of sale in which the servant is able to establish equality and inequality, so as not to lead to prohibiting the incapable. So whatever does not fall under the standard of equality is outside the implication of the Hadith. Among the forms of Explanation of Change is if he says: 'I owe Fulan a thousand as a deposit.' His saying 'I owe' implies obligation...

...and by his saying 'a deposit,' he changed it to preservation. And his saying 'You gave me' or 'You lent me a thousand but I did not receive it' is from the totality of Explanation of Change. Likewise if he said: 'I owe Fulan a thousand bad coins (Zuyuf).' The ruling of Explanation of Change is that it is valid when connected [to the speech] and is not valid when separated. Then after this, there are issues in which the scholars differed whether they are from the totality of Explanation of Change, thus valid with the condition of connection, or from the totality of Explanation of Alteration (Abrogation), thus not valid. A part of this will come in the Explanation of Alteration.

Discussion on Explanation of Necessity (Bayan al-Darurah) and Explanation of Circumstance (Bayan al-Hal). Section: As for Explanation of Necessity, its example is in the saying of the Exalted {And his parents inherit from him, so for his mother is one-third}. He established partnership between the parents, then explained the mother's share, so that became an explanation for the father's share. Based on this, we said: If they explain the share of the Mudarib (worker) and remain silent about the share of the capital owner, the partnership is valid. Likewise, if they explain the share of the capital owner and remain silent about the share of the Mudarib, it is an explanation. Based on this is the ruling of agricultural partnership (Muzara'ah). Likewise, if he bequeathed a thousand to Fulan and Fulan, then explained the share of one of them, that was an explanation for the share of the other. If he divorced one of his two wives then had intercourse with one of them, that is an explanation of the divorce for the other. This is contrary to intercourse in the case of ambiguous manumission according to Abu Hanifa, because the lawfulness of intercourse regarding bondmaids is established by two methods, so the direction of ownership is not specified by considering the lawfulness of intercourse. Section: As for Explanation of Circumstance, its example is when the Lawgiver sees a matter directly witnessed and does not forbid it...

...his silence is in the status of an explanation that it is legislated. And the pre-emptor (Shafi'), if he learns of the sale and remains silent, that is in the status of an explanation that he is pleased with it. And the virgin, if she learns of the guardian's marrying her off and remains silent about rejecting, that is in the status of an explanation of consent and permission. And the master, if he sees his slave buying and selling in the market and remains silent, that is in the status of permission, so he becomes authorized in trade. And the defendant, if he refuses [the oath] in the court session, the refusal is in the status of consent to the obligation of the money by way of acknowledgement according to them [the two disciples], or by way of offering according to Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him. The conclusion is that silence in a place where explanation is needed is in the status of explanation. By this method, we said Consensus (Ijma') is concluded by the text of some and the silence of the rest.

Discussion on Explanation of Conjunction (Bayan al-Atf). Section: As for Explanation of Conjunction, it is like conjoining a measured or weighed item to an ambiguous clause; that becomes an explanation for the ambiguous clause. An example is if he says: 'I owe Fulan a hundred dirhams' or 'a hundred and a Qafiz of wheat'; the conjunction is in the status of explanation that the whole is from that genus. Likewise if he says 'One hundred and three garments' or 'One hundred and three dirhams' or 'One hundred and three slaves,' it is an explanation that the hundred is of that genus, in the status of his saying 'twenty-one dirhams.' This is contrary to his saying 'A hundred and a garment' or 'A hundred and a sheep,' where that is not an explanation for the hundred. This is specific to the conjunction of the single [unit] with what is suitable as a debt in the liability, like measured and weighed items. Abu Yusuf, may Allah have mercy on him, said: It is an explanation in 'A hundred and a sheep' and 'A hundred and a garment' according to this principle.

Discussion on the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Section: As for Explanation of Alteration, which is Abrogation (Naskh), that is permissible from the Lawgiver and not permissible from the servants. Based on this, the exception of the whole from the whole is void because it is abrogating the ruling. And retracting an acknowledgement, divorce, and manumission is not permissible because it is abrogation, and the servant does not have that right. If he says 'I owe Fulan a thousand as a loan or price of a sold item,' and says 'and they are bad coins (Zuyuf),' that is Explanation of Change according to them, so it is valid when connected. But it is Explanation of Alteration according to Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, so it is not valid even if connected. If he says 'I owe Fulan a thousand from the price of a bondmaid he sold me and I did not receive, and the bondmaid has no trace,' that is Explanation of Alteration according to Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, because the acknowledgement of the obligation of the price is an acknowledgement of receipt upon the destruction of the sold item; for if it perished before receipt, the sale would be annulled so the price would not remain obligatory. The Second Discussion: Regarding the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, which is more than the number of sand and pebbles.

Section on the divisions of the Report (Khabar). The report of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, is in the status of the Book regarding the obligation of knowledge and action upon it, for whoever obeys him has obeyed Allah. So what was mentioned regarding the discussion of the Specific, General, Shared, and Ambivalent in the Book applies likewise regarding the Sunnah, except that the doubt in the chapter of the Report is in its establishment from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and its connection to him. For this meaning, the Report became of three divisions: 1. A division that is authentic from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and established from him without doubt; this is the Mutawatir (Mass-Transmitted). 2. A division in which there is a type of doubt; this is the Mashhur (Famous). 3. A division in which there is probability and doubt; this is the Ahad (Solitary).

Discussion on the Mutawatir necessitating definitive knowledge. The Mutawatir is what a group transmitted from a group whose agreement on a lie is inconceivable due to their large number, and it connected to you in this manner. Examples of it are the transmission of the Qur'an, the numbers of Rak'ahs, and the amounts of Zakat. The Mashhur is what was initially like the Ahad, then it became famous in the second and third eras, and the Ummah received it with acceptance, so it became like the Mutawatir until it connected to you. That is like the Hadith of wiping over the leather socks and stoning in the chapter of adultery. Then, the Mutawatir necessitates definitive knowledge, and rejecting it is Disbelief (Kufr). The Mashhur necessitates the knowledge of tranquility, and rejecting it is Innovation (Bid'ah). There is no disagreement among scholars regarding the obligation of acting upon both. The discussion is only regarding the Ahad. We say: The Solitary Report (Khabar al-Wahid) is what one transmitted from one, or one from a group, or a group from one, and there is no consideration for the number if it does not reach the limit of the Mashhur. It necessitates action upon it in legal rulings with the condition of the narrator's Islam, justice, precision, and intellect, and that it connects to you from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with this condition.

Discussion on dividing the narrator into two categories. Then, the narrator is originally of two categories: 1. Known for knowledge and Ijtihad, like the four Caliphs, Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, Abdullah ibn Abbas, Abdullah ibn Umar, Zayd ibn Thabit, Mu'adh ibn Jabal, and their likes, may Allah be pleased with them. So if their narration from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, is authentic to you, acting upon their narration is preferred over acting upon Analogy (Qiyas). For this reason, Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, narrated the Hadith of the Bedouin who had an ailment in his eye regarding the issue of loud laughter and abandoned Qiyas. And he narrated the Hadith of placing women behind in the issue of alignment and abandoned Qiyas. And he narrated from Aisha the Hadith of vomiting and abandoned Qiyas by it. And he narrated from Ibn Mas'ud the Hadith of prostration of forgetfulness after the Salam and abandoned Qiyas. The second category of narrators are those known for memory and justice but not Ijtihad and Fatwa, like Abu Huraira and Anas ibn Malik. If the narration of their likes is authentic to you, if the report agrees with Qiyas, there is no obscurity in the obligation to act upon it. But if it opposes it, acting upon Qiyas is preferred. An example is what Abu Huraira narrated regarding ablution from what fire has touched...

...so Ibn Abbas said to him: 'Do you see if you performed ablution with heated water, would you perform ablution [again] from it?' And he remained silent. He only rejected it by Qiyas; for if he had a report, he would have narrated it. Based on this, our companions abandoned the narration of Abu Huraira in the issue of the Musarrah (animal with retained milk) due to Qiyas and considering the difference in the states of the narrators.

Discussion on the condition of acting upon the Solitary Report. We said: The condition for acting upon the Solitary Report is that it must not be contrary to the Book and the Famous Sunnah, and that it must not be contrary to the Apparent (Zahir). He said, peace be upon him: (Hadiths will multiply for you after me. So if a Hadith is narrated to you from me, compare it against the Book of Allah; whatever agrees, accept it, and whatever opposes, reject it). The verification of that is in what was narrated from Ali ibn Abi Talib, that he said: Narrators were of three categories: 1. A sincere believer who accompanied the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and knew the meaning of his speech. 2. A Bedouin who came from a tribe, heard some of what he heard but did not know the reality of the speech of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, then returned to his tribe and narrated with other than the wording of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so the meaning changed while he thought the meaning did not differ. 3. A hypocrite whose hypocrisy was not known, so he narrated what he did not hear and fabricated; people heard from him and thought him a sincere believer, so they narrated that and it became famous among people. For this meaning, it became obligatory to compare the Report against the Book and the Famous Sunnah. An example of comparing against the Book is in the Hadith of touching the penis, regarding what is narrated from him: (Whoever touches his penis, let him perform ablution). We compared it against the Book, and it came out contrary to the saying of the Exalted {In it are men who love to purify themselves}, for they used to clean themselves with stones then wash with water. If touching the penis were an event breaking ritual purity, this would be defilement, not purification absolutely. Likewise his saying, peace be upon him: (Any woman who marries herself without the permission of her guardian, her marriage is void, void, void) came out contrary to the saying of the Exalted {Do not prevent them from marrying their husbands}...

...for the Book necessitates the realization of marriage from them. An example of comparing against the Famous Report is the narration of judging based on a witness and an oath; for it came out contrary to his saying, upon him be [peace]: (The evidence is upon the claimant and the oath is upon the denier).

Discussion on abandoning action upon the Solitary Report if it opposes the Apparent. Considering this meaning, we said: If the Solitary Report comes out contrary to the Apparent, it is not acted upon. Among the forms of opposing the Apparent is the lack of fame of the Report regarding matters of general necessity in the first and second eras, because they are not accused of negligence in following the Sunnah. So if the Report does not become famous despite the intense need and general necessity, that is a sign of its lack of authenticity. An example in legal judgments: If one person informs that his wife became forbidden to him due to breastfeeding that occurred [later], it is permissible to rely on his report and marry her sister. But if he informed that the contract was void by the ruling of breastfeeding [initially], his report is not accepted. Likewise, if a woman informs of the death of her husband or his divorcing her while he is absent, it is permissible [for her] to rely on his report and marry another. If the Qiblah is confusing to him and one person informs him about it, acting upon it is obligatory. If he finds blood [or fluid] whose state he does not know, and one person informs him of its impurity, he does not perform ablution with it; rather, he performs Tayammum.

Discussion on the authority of the Solitary Report in four places. Section: The Solitary Report is a proof in four places: [1] Pure right of Allah the Exalted which is not a punishment. [2] Pure right of the servant which involves pure obligation. [3] Pure right of His [implied servant/Allah] which involves no obligation. [4] Pure right of His [or servant] which involves obligation from one perspective. As for the first, the report of one person is accepted in it, for the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, accepted the testimony of a Bedouin regarding the crescent of Ramadan. As for the second, number and justice are conditions in it; its parallel is disputes. As for the third, the report of a single person is accepted in it, whether just or unrighteous; its parallel is transactions. As for the fourth, either number or justice is a condition in it according to Abu Hanifa, may Allah be pleased with him; its parallel is dismissal [of an agent] and interdiction. The Third Discussion: On Consensus (Ijma'). Section: The Consensus of this Ummah after the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, passed away regarding branches...

...of the religion is a proof necessitating action upon it legally, as an honor to this Ummah. Then Consensus is of four divisions: 1. Consensus of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, on the ruling of an incident explicitly. 2. Then their consensus by the text of some and the silence of the rest regarding rejection.

Discussion on Consensus being of four divisions. 3. Then the consensus of those after them regarding what the statement of the predecessors was not found in. 4. Then the consensus on one of the statements of the predecessors. As for the first, it is in the status of a verse from the Book of Allah the Exalted. Then the consensus by the text of some and the silence of the rest is in the status of the Mutawatir. Then the consensus of those after them is in the status of the Mashhur of reports. Then the consensus of the later scholars on one of the statements of the predecessors is in the status of the Authentic of the Solitary Reports. What is considered in this chapter is the consensus of the people of opinion and Ijtihad; the statement of the commoners, the theologian, and the hadith scholar who has no insight into the principles of jurisprudence is not considered. Then after that, Consensus is of two types: Compound and Non-Compound. Compound is what opinions agreed upon regarding the ruling of the incident while differing in the cause. An example is the consensus on the existence of [wudu] breakage upon vomiting and touching a woman. According to us, it is based on vomiting; and according to him [Shafi'i], it is based on touching. Then this type of consensus does not remain a proof after the appearance of invalidity...

...in one of the two bases. So if it is established that vomiting is not a breaker, Abu Hanifa does not say there is breakage in it. And if it is established that touching is not a breaker, Al-Shafi'i does not say there is breakage in it, due to the invalidity of the cause upon which the ruling was built. And the invalidity is imagined in both sides, due to the possibility that Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, is correct in the issue of touching [that it doesn't break] and mistaken in the issue of vomiting, and Al-Shafi'i is correct in the issue of vomiting [that it doesn't break] and mistaken in the issue of touching. So this does not lead to building the existence of consensus on falsehood.

Discussion on a type of Consensus which is the absence of a proponent of separation. Section: Contrary to the previously mentioned consensus. The conclusion is that the lifting of this consensus is permissible due to the appearance of invalidity in what it was built upon. For this reason, if a judge judges in an incident, then the slavery of the witnesses appears, or their lying [is proven] by retraction, his judgment becomes void, even if that does not appear regarding the right of the claimant. Considering this meaning, [the share of] 'those whose hearts are to be reconciled' dropped from the eight categories due to the cessation of the cause. And the share of the relatives dropped due to the cessation of its cause. Based on this, if an impure garment is washed with vinegar so the impurity is removed, the purity of the locus is judged due to the cessation of its cause [the impurity]. Or by this, the difference between Hadath (ritual impurity) and Khabath (physical impurity) is established; for vinegar removes impurity from the locus, but vinegar does not provide purity of the locus, rather the purifier provides it, which is water. Section: Then after that is a type of Consensus, which is the absence of a proponent of separation. That is of two types: One of them is when the origin of the disagreement in the two sections is one.

Allah Blessed and Exalted, may Allah be pleased with them, the Lord Mighty and Majestic. And the second is when the origin is different. The first is a proof, and the second is not a proof. An example of the first is in what the scholars derived of jurisprudential issues based on a single principle. Its parallel: If we establish that the prohibition of legal disposals necessitates their confirmation, we say: A vow to fast on the Day of Sacrifice is valid, and a corrupt sale provides ownership, due to the absence of a proponent of separation. If we say that suspension is a cause upon the existence of the condition, we say: Suspending divorce and manumission on ownership [is valid], and the cause of ownership is valid. Likewise, if we establish that arranging a ruling on a noun described with an attribute does not necessitate suspending the ruling on it, we say: The affluence of a free woman does not prevent the permissibility of marrying a bondmaid, since it is authentic by the transfer of the predecessors that Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, branched the issue of the free woman's affluence on this principle. If we establish the permissibility of marrying a believing bondmaid despite affluence, the marriage of a Kitabi bondmaid is permissible by this principle. Based on this is the example of what we mentioned previously. The parallel of the second: If we say that vomiting is a breaker, then corrupt sale provides ownership due to the absence of a proponent of separation. Or intentional killing necessitates retaliation due to the absence of a proponent of separation. Or like this: Vomiting is not a breaker, so touching is a breaker. This is not a proof, because the correctness of the branch, although it indicates the correctness of its origin, it does not necessitate the correctness of another origin until the other issue branches from it.

Discussion on the explanation of the duty upon the Mujtahid. Section: The duty upon the Mujtahid is to seek the ruling of the incident from the Book of Allah the Exalted, then from the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, by the explicit text or its indication as mentioned before. For there is no way to act upon opinion (Ra'y) with the possibility of acting upon the Text. For this reason, if the Qiblah is confusing to him and one person informs him about it, it is not permissible for him to investigate. And if he finds water and a just person informs him that it is impure, it is not permissible for him to perform ablution with it; rather, he performs Tayammum. Considering that acting upon opinion is inferior to acting upon the Text, we said that doubt in the locus is stronger than doubt in the conjecture, such that the consideration of the servant's conjecture drops in the first section. An example is if he has intercourse with his son's bondmaid; he is not punished (Hadd) even if he says 'I knew she is forbidden to me,' and the lineage of the child is established from him, because the doubt of ownership is established by the Text in the son's wealth. He said, upon him be blessings and peace: (You and your wealth belong to your father). So the consideration of his conjecture regarding lawfulness and prohibition drops in that. But if the son has intercourse with his father's bondmaid, his conjecture regarding lawfulness and prohibition is considered, such that if he said 'I thought she was forbidden to me,' the Hadd is obligatory.

And if he says: "I thought that she was lawful for me," the Hadd (punishment) is not obligated. This is because the doubt of ownership (Shubhat al-Mulk) regarding the father's wealth is established by the Text, so his opinion is considered. However, the lineage of the child is not established even if he claims it.

Discussion: What the Mujtahid does when two proofs contradict.
Then, if two proofs contradict according to the Mujtahid: If the contradiction is between two Verses, he leans towards the Sunnah. If it is between two Sunnahs, he leans towards the traces of the Companions, may Allah Almighty be pleased with them, and sound Analogy (Qiyas). Then, if two Analogies contradict according to the Mujtahid, he investigates (yataharr'a) and acts upon one of them, because there is no legal proof inferior to Analogy to which one can resort.
Based on this, we said: If a traveler has two vessels, one pure and one impure, he does not investigate between them; rather, he performs Tayammum. But if he has two garments, one pure and one impure, he investigates between them. This is because water has a substitute, which is soil, while the garment has no substitute to resort to.
It is established by this that acting upon opinion (Ra'y) is only upon the absence of other evidence in the Sharia.
Then, if he investigates and his investigation is confirmed by action, that is not annulled by mere [later] investigation. Its explanation is in the case where he investigates between two garments and prays Dhuhr in one of them, then his investigation for Asr falls upon the other garment; it is not permissible for him to pray Asr in the other. This is because the first [opinion] was confirmed by action, so it is not invalidated by mere investigation.
This is contrary to the case where he investigates the Qibla, then his opinion changes and his investigation falls upon another direction; he turns towards it. This is because the Qibla accepts transition (Intiqal), so moving the...
...ruling is possible, similar to the abrogation of a Text. Upon this are the issues of Al-Jami' Al-Kabir regarding the Takbirs of Eid and the changing of the slave's opinion, as is known.

Discussion: The Authority of Analogy (Qiyas) and the Obligation to Act upon it.
The Fourth Discussion: Chapter on Analogy (Qiyas).
Analogy is one of the proofs of the Sharia. It is obligatory to act upon it when there is an absence of superior evidence regarding the incident. Reports and Traces have been narrated concerning this.
Upon sending Mu'adh bin Jabal to Yemen, he (the Prophet), peace and blessings be upon him, said: "By what will you judge, O Mu'adh?" He said: "By the Book of Allah Almighty." He said: "If you do not find [it there]?" He said: "By the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace." He said: "If you do not find [it there]?" He said: "I will strive with my opinion (Ajiahidu Ra'yi)." The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, approved of him and said: "Praise be to Allah Who guided the messenger of the Messenger of Allah to what He loves and is pleased with."
It was narrated that a Khath'ami woman came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and said: "Indeed, my father is an old man; the Hajj has become obligatory upon him but he cannot hold himself upon the mount. Does it suffice me to perform Hajj on his behalf?" He, peace be upon him, said: "Do you see, if your father had a debt and you paid it, would it suffice you?" She said: "Yes." He, peace be upon him, said: "Then the debt of Allah is more worthy and deserving."
The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, joined the Hajj regarding the senile old man with financial rights, and he indicated an effective cause (Illah) influential in permissibility, which is "Paying/Fulfillment" (Al-Qada'). And this is Analogy (Qiyas).

Discussion: Reports that Establish the Authority of Analogy.
1 - Ibn al-Sabbagh, who is among the leaders of the Shafi'i scholars, narrated in his book named "Al-Shamil" from Qays bin Talq bin Ali that he said: A man came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, appearing to be a Bedouin, and said: "O Prophet of Allah, what do you say about a man touching his penis after he has performed Wudu?" He said: "Is it but a piece of flesh from him?" And this is Analogy.
2 - And Ibn Mas'ud was asked about one who married a woman and did not name a dowry for her, and her husband died before consummation. He asked for a month's respite, then said: "I will strive in it with my opinion. If it is correct, it is from Allah, and if it is a mistake, it is from Ibn Umm Abd (himself)." He said: "I see for her a dowry similar to that of her womenfolk (Mahr al-Mithl), without reduction and without excess."

Discussion: The Conditions for the Validity of Analogy are Five.
Chapter: The conditions for the validity of Analogy are five.
First: That it does not oppose the Text.
Second: That it does not imply changing a ruling of the Text.
Third: That the extended ruling is not one whose meaning is beyond reason (La Ya'qilu Ma'nahu).
Fourth: That the reasoning (Ta'lil) occurs for a legal matter, not for a linguistic matter.
Fifth: That the Branch (Al-Far') is not already specified in the Text.

An example of Analogy opposing the Text is what is narrated that Al-Hasan bin Ziyad was asked about loud laughter (Qahqahah) in prayer. He said: "Purity is broken by it." The questioner said: "If one slanders a chaste woman during prayer, Wudu is not broken by it, even though slandering a chaste woman is a greater crime. So how is it broken by laughter, which is lesser than it?" This is an Analogy opposing the Text, which is the Hadith of the Bedouin who had an ailment in his eyes.
Likewise, if we said: "The Hajj of a woman is permissible with a Mahram, so it is permissible with trustworthy women," this would be an Analogy opposing the Text, which is his saying, peace be upon him: "It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day to travel for more than three days and nights unless her father, husband, or a Mahram relative is with her."

An example of the Second, which is what implies changing a ruling of the Text, is what is said: "Intention (Niyyah) is a condition in Wudu by Analogy to Tayammum." For this necessitates...
...changing the Verse of Wudu from Absoluteness (Itlaq) to Restriction (Taqyid).

Discussion: Clarifying Examples of the Conditions of Analogy.
Likewise, if we say: "Tawaf around the House is Prayer according to the Report, so Purity and covering the 'Awrah are conditions for it like Prayer," this would be an Analogy necessitating the change of the Text of Tawaf from Absoluteness to Restriction.

An example of the Third, which is what is beyond reason (cannot be rationalized), is regarding the permissibility of performing Wudu with Date Nabidh (Infusion). If one said: "It is permissible with other types of Nabidh by Analogy to Date Nabidh," or said: "If one receives a wound in his prayer or has a wet dream, he builds upon his prayer by Analogy to the case where Hadath (impurity) precedes him [accidentally]," it is not valid. This is because the ruling in the Original (Asl) is not rationalized in its meaning, so extending it to the Branch is impossible.
Similar to this is what the Shafi'i scholars, may Allah have mercy on them, said: "Two impure Qullahs (large jars), if they combine, become pure. So if they separate, they remain upon purity by Analogy to when impurity falls into two Qullahs." Because the ruling, if established in the Original, would have a meaning that is not rational.

An example of the Fourth, which is that the reasoning be for a legal matter not a linguistic matter, is in their saying: "Cooked juice (Monassaf) is Khamr (Wine), because Khamr is only Khamr because it clouds (Khamara) the mind, and the other clouds the mind as well, so it is Khamr by Analogy." And: "The thief (Sariq) is only a thief because he took the wealth of another by way of stealth, and the grave-robber (Nabash) shares this meaning with him, so he is a thief by Analogy." This is Analogy in Language, despite his admission that the Name was not coined for it in the language.

The evidence for the corruption of this type of Analogy is that the Arab calls the horse "Adham" due to its blackness and "Kumayt" due to its reddish-blackness, yet he does not apply this name to the Zanj (black person) or the red garment. If Analogy were valid in linguistic names, that would have been permissible due to the existence of the Cause (Illah). Also, because this leads to invalidating legal causes (Asbab). That is because the Sharia made Theft a cause for a type of ruling; so if we suspend the ruling on what is more general than Theft—which is taking another's property by way of stealth—it becomes clear that the cause in the Original was a meaning other than Theft. Likewise, it made drinking Khamr a cause for a type of ruling; so if we suspend the ruling on a matter more general than Khamr, it becomes clear that the ruling in the Original was attached to other than Khamr.

An example of the Fifth Condition, which is (That the Branch is not already specified in the Text), is as it is said: "Freeing a disbelieving neck (slave) in the expiation (Kaffarah) of Oaths and Dhihar is not permissible by Analogy to the expiation of Murder." And: "If the one doing Dhihar has intercourse during the feeding, he restarts the feeding by Analogy to Fasting." And: "It is permissible for the Muhsar (blocked pilgrim) to decompose (Tahallul) by Fasting by Analogy to the Mutamatti'." And: "The Mutamatti', if he does not fast during the days of Tashriq, fasts after them by Analogy to the makeup (Qada') of Ramadan."

Discussion: Defining Legal Analogy (Qiyas Shar'i)
Chapter: Legal Analogy is the arrangement of a ruling in a non-textual case based on a meaning that is the Cause (Illah) for that ruling in the textual case.
Furthermore, the status of the meaning as a Cause is known by the Book, the Sunnah, Consensus (Ijma'), and by Ijtihad and Deduction (Istinbat).

Discussion: The Cause Known by the Book
An example of the Cause known by the Book is "Frequent Circulation" (Kathrat al-Tawaf). It was made a Cause for the dropping of difficulty (Haraj) in seeking permission [to enter] in His Almighty's saying: {There is no blame upon you nor upon them after that; [they are] those who circulate among you, some of you among others} [24:58].
Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, dropped the difficulty of the impurity of the cat's saliva by the ruling of this Cause, saying, peace be upon him: "The cat is not impure; indeed, it is of those who circulate among you (Al-Tawwafin) and those (females) who circulate (Al-Tawwafat)."
So our companions drew an analogy for all that resides in houses, such as the mouse and the snake, to the cat based on the Cause of Circulation (Tawaf).

Likewise, His Almighty's saying: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship} [2:185]. The Sharia clarified that breaking the fast for the sick and the traveler is to make the matter easy for them, so that they may be able to realize what they deem preferable: either performing the duty of the time or delaying it to other days.

Considering this meaning, Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, said: If the traveler intends another duty during the days of Ramadan, it counts for the other duty.
