Because since concessions were established for him regarding what relates to the interests of his body—which is breaking the fast—then for that to be established for him regarding what relates to the interests of his religion—which is discharging the self from the liability of duty—is even more fitting.

Discussion: The Cause Known by the Sunnah
An example of the Cause known by the Sunnah is in his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Wudu is not upon one who sleeps standing, sitting, bowing, or prostrating; Wudu is only upon one who sleeps reclining." For if he sleeps reclining, his joints relax. He made the relaxation of joints a Cause. Thus, the ruling extends by this Cause to sleeping while leaning or propped against something such that if it were removed, he would fall. Likewise, the ruling extends by this Cause to fainting and intoxication.
Likewise, his saying, peace be upon him: "Perform Wudu and pray, even if blood drips onto the mat drippingly, for it is a vein that burst." He made the bursting of blood a Cause, so the ruling extends by this Cause to Venesection (Fasd) and Cupping (Hijama).

An example of the Cause known by Consensus (Ijma') is what we said: "Minority" (Sighar) is a Cause for the guardianship of the father regarding the young boy, so the ruling is established regarding the young girl due to the existence of the Cause. And "Puberty with Reason" is a Cause for the removal of the father's guardianship regarding the boy, so the ruling extends to the girl by this Cause. And the bursting of blood is a Cause for the breaking of Purity regarding the woman with Istihadah, so the ruling extends to others due to the existence of the Cause.

Then after that, we say: Analogy is of two types.

The first is that the Extended Ruling is of the same Type (Nau') as the ruling established in the Original. The second is that it is of its Genus (Jins).
An example of Unity in Type is what we said: That Minority is a Cause for the guardianship of marriage regarding the boy, so the guardianship of marriage is established regarding the girl due to the existence of the Cause in her. And by it, the ruling is established regarding the minor non-virgin (Thayyib).

Discussion: The Cause Derived by Consensus [Analogy of Genus]
Likewise, we said: Circulation (Tawaf) is the Cause for the dropping of impurity of saliva in the cat's saliva, so the ruling extends to the saliva of the dwellers of houses due to the existence of the Cause. And the Puberty of the boy with reason is the Cause for the removal of marriage guardianship, so the guardianship is removed from the girl by the rule of this Cause.

An example of Unity in Genus is what is said: Frequent Circulation (Tawaf) is the Cause for dropping the difficulty of Seeking Permission regarding those whom our right hands possess (slaves), so the difficulty of the impurity of saliva drops by this Cause. For indeed, this difficulty is of the Genus of that difficulty, not of its Type.
Likewise, Minority is the Cause for the father's guardianship of disposal regarding Property, so the guardianship of disposal regarding the Self (Marriage) is established by the rule of this Cause. And indeed, the puberty of the girl with reason is the Cause for the removal of the father's guardianship regarding Property, so his guardianship regarding the Self is removed by this Cause.
Then, in this type of Analogy, it is necessary to Generalize the Cause (Tajnis al-Illah), by saying: The father's guardianship regarding the property of the minor girl is only established because she is incapable of disposal by herself; so the Sharia established the father's guardianship so that her interests related to that would not be neglected. And she is incapable of disposal regarding herself, so holding the father's guardianship over her becomes obligatory. And upon this are its counterparts.

The rule of the First Analogy is that it is not invalidated by the Distinction (Al-Farq), because the Original and the Branch, when they are united in the Cause, their unity in the Ruling is obligatory, even if they differ in other than this Cause.
The rule of the Second Analogy is its corruption by prohibiting the Generalization (Muman'at al-Tajnis) and by Specific Distinction (Al-Farq Al-Khass), which is showing that the effect of Minority in the guardianship of disposal regarding Property is stronger than its effect in the guardianship of disposal regarding the Self.

Discussion: The Cause Known by Opinion and Ijtihad
The explanation of the Third Division, which is Analogy by a Cause deduced by Opinion and Ijtihad, is apparent.
The verification of that is: If we find a description suitable (Munasib) for the ruling, and it is such that it necessitates the establishment of the ruling and requires it upon considering it, and the ruling is paired with it in the place of Consensus; the ruling is attributed to it due to suitability, not due to the testimony of the Sharia that it is a Cause.
Its counterpart is: If we see a person giving a Dirham to a poor man, it predominates in opinion that the giving is to repel the need of the poor man and to acquire the benefits of reward.
If this is known, we say: If we see a description suitable for the ruling, and the ruling is paired with it in the place of Consensus, opinion predominates to attribute the ruling to that description. Predominance of opinion (Ghalabat al-Zann) in the Sharia necessitates action when superior evidence is lacking. It is like the traveler: if it predominates in his opinion that water is near him, Tayammum is not permissible for him. Upon this are the issues of Investigation (Taharri).
The rule of this Analogy is that it is invalidated by a Suitable Distinction (Al-Farq Al-Munasib). Because in that case, there exists another suitable factor in the form of the ruling, so the opinion of attributing the ruling to it [the first cause] does not remain. Thus, the ruling is not established by it, because it was based on the predominance of opinion, and that has been annulled by the Distinction.
Based on this, acting upon the First Type was like judging by testimony after the validation (Tazkiyah) and probity check of the witness.
And the Second Type is like testimony upon the appearance of justice before the validation (Tazkiyah). And the Third Type is like the testimony of the one of unknown status (Mastur).

Discussion: The Objections Directed at Analogy
Chapter: The Objections directed at Analogy are eight: Denial (Al-Muman'ah), Saying according to the Implication of the Cause (Al-Qawl bi-Mujab al-Illah), Inversion (Al-Qalb), Reversal (Al-'Aks), Corruption of Placement (Fasad al-Wad'), Distinction (Al-Farq), Inconsistency (Al-Naqd), and Contradiction (Al-Mu'arada).
As for Denial (Al-Muman'ah), it is of two types: First is denying the Description (Wasf). Second is denying the Ruling (Hukm).
An example [of denying the Ruling] is in their saying: "Sadaqat al-Fitr became obligatory due to the Breaking of Fast (Fitr), so it does not drop by his death on the night of Fitr." We said: We do not concede its obligation due to Fitr; rather, according to us, it is obligatory due to a 'Head' (Ra's) that he supports and has guardianship over.
Likewise, if it is said: "The amount of Zakat is obligatory in the liability (Dhimmah), so it does not drop by the destruction of the Nisab, like a debt." We said: We do not concede that the amount of Zakat is obligatory in the liability; rather, its performance is obligatory. And if he says: "Its performance is obligatory, so it does not drop by destruction, like a debt after the demand." We said: We do not concede that performance is obligatory in the form of a debt; rather, withholding is prohibited until he discharges the responsibility by releasing [the wealth]. This is of the category of denying the Ruling.
Likewise, if he says: "Wiping is a pillar in the chapter of Wudu, so tripling it is not [Sunnah] like Washing."

We said: We do not concede that tripling is Sunnah in Washing; rather, prolonging the action on the locus of the obligation is an addition to the obligatory, like prolonging the standing and recitation in the chapter of Prayer. However, prolonging in the chapter of Washing is not imaginable except by repetition to encompass the locus with the action. And we say the like thereof in the chapter of Wiping: that prolonging is Sunnah by way of Encompassing (Istia'ab).
Likewise, it is said: "Taking possession (Taqabud) in the sale of food for food is a condition, like Money (Nuqud)." We said: We do not concede that Taqabud is a condition in the chapter of Money; rather, the condition is Specification (Ta'yin) so that it does not become a sale of debt for debt. However, Money is not specified except by Taking Possession according to us.

Discussion: Saying according to the Implication of the Cause (Al-Qawl bi-Mujab al-Illah)
As for "Saying according to the Implication of the Cause," it is admitting that the Description is a Cause, but clarifying that its Effect (Ma'lul) is other than what the Proponent claimed.
An example is: "The elbow is a Limit (Hadd) in the chapter of Wudu, so it does not enter under the washing, because the Limit does not enter into the Limited." We said: The elbow is the Limit of the Dropped part, so it does not enter under the ruling of the Dropped part, because the Limit does not enter into the Limited [thus it remains washed].
Likewise, it is said: "The Fast of Ramadan is an obligatory Fast, so it is not valid without Specification (Ta'yin), like Makeup (Qada')." We said: The obligatory fast is not valid without Specification, except that Specification exists here from the side of the Sharia. And if he says: "The Fast of Ramadan is not valid without Specification from the Servant, like Qada'." We said: Qada' is not valid without Specification because Specification was not established from the side of the Sharia in Qada', so for that reason, the Servant's specification is conditioned. But here, Specification is found from the side of the Sharia, so the Servant's specification is not conditioned.

As for Inversion (Al-Qalb), it is of two types.
One of them is that he makes what the Proponent made a Cause for the ruling, an Effect for that ruling.
An example in legal matters: "The flow of Riba in the large quantity necessitates its flow in the small quantity, like Prices (Athman), so selling a handful of food for two handfuls of it is prohibited."

We said: No, rather the flow of Riba in the small quantity necessitates its flow in the large quantity, like Prices.
Likewise in the issue of the refugee in the Haram (Sanctuary): "The prohibition of destroying the Soul necessitates the prohibition of destroying the Limb, like Game." We said: Rather, the prohibition of destroying the Limb necessitates the prohibition of destroying the Soul, like Game. So if you made its Cause an Effect for that ruling, it does not remain a Cause for it, due to the impossibility of one thing being a Cause for a thing and an Effect for it.

Discussion: Dividing Inversion (Al-Qalb) into Two Parts
The Second Type of Inversion is that the Questioner makes what the Proponent made a Cause for the ruling he claimed, a Cause for the opposite of that ruling. Thus, it becomes a proof for the Questioner after it was a proof for the Proponent.
An example is: "The Fast of Ramadan is an obligatory Fast, so Specification is a condition for it, like Makeup (Qada')." We said: Since the Fast is obligatory [and time-fixed], Specification is not a condition for it after the day has been specified for it, like Qada' [would be if fixed].

As for Reversal (Al-'Aks), we mean by it that the Questioner holds on to the Proponent's principle in a way that the Proponent is forced into the mode of comparison between the Original and the Branch.
An example is: "Jewelry prepared for daily use (Ibtidhal); Zakat is not obligatory in it, like clothes for daily use." We said: If Jewelry were in the status of Clothes, Zakat would not be obligatory in men's jewelry, like clothes for daily use.

Discussion on the Converse (Aks), Invalidity of Placement (Fasad al-Wad'), and Inconsistency (Naqd). As for Invalidity of Placement, what is meant by it is making a description a Cause ('Illah) that is not suitable for that ruling. An example of this is their statement regarding the Islam of one of the spouses: 'Difference of religion has occurred upon the marriage, so it corrupts it, like the apostasy of one of the spouses.' For he made Islam a cause for the removal of ownership [of marriage]. We said: Islam is known to be a protector of ownership, so it cannot be effective in the removal of ownership. Likewise, in the issue of the affluence of a free woman: 'He is a free man capable of marriage [to a free woman], so marrying a bondmaid is not permissible for him, just as if he had a free woman under him.' We said: The description of being free and capable implies the permissibility of marriage, so it cannot be effective in the non-permissibility. As for Inconsistency (Naqd), it is like what is said: 'Ablution is a purification, so intention is a condition for it, like Tayammum.' We said: This is inconsistent [breached] by the washing of a garment and a vessel. As for Opposition (Mu'aradah), it is like what is said: 'Wiping is a pillar in ablution, so performing it thrice is Sunnah, like washing.' We said: Wiping is a pillar, so performing it thrice is not Sunnah, like wiping over leather socks and Tayammum.

Section: The Ruling relates to its Cause (Sabab), is established by its Effective Cause ('Illah), and is found at its Condition (Shart). The Cause (Sabab) is that which is a path to a thing through a medium, like a road; for it is a cause for arriving at the destination through the medium of walking. And the rope; for it is a cause for reaching water by letting the bucket down. Based on this, whatever is a path to a ruling through a medium is called a Cause (Sabab) for it legally, and the medium is called the Effective Cause ('Illah). An example of this is opening the door of the stable and cutting the tether of the slave; for it is a cause of the destruction through the medium found from the animal, the bird, and the slave.

Discussion on the difference between the Cause (Sabab) and the Effective Cause ('Illah). When the Cause and the Effective Cause come together, the ruling is attributed to the Effective Cause, not the Cause, unless attributing it to the Effective Cause is impossible; then it is attributed to the Cause. Based on this, our companions said: If one gives a knife to a boy and he kills himself with it, he [the giver] is not liable. But if it falls from the boy's hand and wounds him, he is liable. If one places a boy on an animal and makes it walk, and it prances right and left, and he falls and dies, he is not liable. If one guides a person to the property of another and he steals it, or to a person and he kills him, or to a caravan and he robs them, liability is not obligatory upon the guide. This is contrary to the depositary if he guides a thief to the deposit and he steals it, or a person in Ihram guides another to the game of the Sanctuary and he kills it. For the obligation of liability on the depositary is due to abandoning the protection obligatory upon him, not due to the guidance. And upon the person in Ihram, it is because guidance is prohibited by his Ihram, like touching perfume and wearing sewn garments, so he is liable for committing the prohibition, not due to the guidance [itself causing the destruction]. However, the crime is only established by the reality of killing; as for before that, it has no ruling due to the possibility of the effect of the crime being lifted, similar to healing in the chapter of wounds.

Discussion on the Cause (Sabab) sometimes being in the meaning of the Effective Cause ('Illah). The Cause may be in the meaning of the Effective Cause, so the ruling is attributed to it. An example is when the Effective Cause is established by the Cause; thus the Cause is in the meaning of the Effective Cause, because since the Effective Cause is established by the Cause, it becomes in the meaning of the 'Cause of the Effective Cause,' so the ruling is attributed to it. For this reason, we said: If one drives an animal and it destroys something, the driver is liable. And the witness, if he destroys wealth by his testimony, then its falsehood appears by retraction, he is liable. This is because the walking of the animal is attributed to the driving, and the judgment of the judge is attributed to the testimony; since he has no choice but to judge after the truth appears via the testimony of a just person before him, he becomes like one compelled in that, similar to the animal by the action of the driver. Then, the Cause may be established in the place of the Effective Cause...

...when it is impossible to ascertain the reality of the Effective Cause, to make the matter easy for the subject (Mukallaf). The consideration of the [actual] Effective Cause drops, and the ruling revolves around the Cause. An example of this in legal matters is complete sleep; since it was established in the place of impurity (Hadath) [escaping gas etc.], the consideration of the reality of impurity drops, and the breaking of wudu revolves around the completeness of sleep. Likewise, valid privacy (Khulwah Sahihah); since it was established in the place of intercourse, the consideration of the reality of intercourse drops, and the ruling revolves around the validity of the privacy regarding the right of the full dowry and the obligation of the waiting period (Iddah). Likewise, travel; since it was established in the place of hardship regarding the concession, the consideration of the reality of hardship drops, and the ruling revolves around the travel itself. Even if a Sultan were to tour the borders of his kingdom intending the distance of travel, he would have the concession of breaking the fast and shortening the prayer. Sometimes, what is not a cause is metaphorically called a cause, like an oath; it is called a cause for expiation, though it is not a cause in reality, for a cause does not negate the existence of the effect, while the oath negates the obligation of expiation, for expiation only becomes obligatory by breaking the oath (Hinth), and by that, the oath ends.

Likewise, suspending a ruling on a condition, like divorce and emancipation, is called a cause metaphorically, but it is not a cause in reality. This is because the ruling is only established at the condition, and the suspension ends with the existence of the condition, so it cannot be a cause with the existence of mutual negation between them.

Discussion on the attachment of legal rulings to their causes. Section: Legal rulings are attached to their causes. This is because the [reality of] obligation is hidden from us, so there must be a sign by which the servant knows the obligation of the ruling. By this consideration, rulings are attributed to causes. So, the cause for the obligation of prayer is the Time, by the proof that the address to perform the prayer is not directed before the entry of the time, but is directed only after the entry of the time. The address (Khitab) establishes the obligation of performance and informs the servant of the cause of obligation before it. This is like our saying: 'Pay the price of the sold item' and 'Pay the maintenance of the wife.' There is nothing existing here that defines it for the servant except the entry of the time. Thus, it becomes clear that the obligation is established by the entry of the time. Also, because the obligation is established upon those whom the address does not cover, like the sleeper and the one who has fainted, and there is no obligation before the time, so it is established by the entry of the time. By this, it appears that the first part [of the time] is the cause for the obligation. Then after that, there are two ways: One of them is the transfer of causality from the first part to the second if he does not perform it in the first part, then to the third and the fourth, until it ends at the last of the time. The obligation is then established [firmly], and the state of the servant in that part is considered, and the attribute of that part is considered. The explanation of considering the state of the servant in it is: If he was a child at the beginning of the time and became an adult in that [last] part...

...or was a disbeliever at the beginning of the time and became Muslim in that part, or she was menstruating or in postpartum bleeding at the beginning of the time and became pure in that part, the prayer becomes obligatory. Based on this are all forms of the occurrence of legal capacity at the end of the time. And conversely: If menstruation, postpartum bleeding, encompassing insanity, or extended fainting occurs in that part, the prayer drops from him. If he was a traveler at the beginning of the time and a resident at its end, he prays four. If he was a resident at the beginning of the time and a traveler at its end, he prays two cycles. The explanation of considering the attribute of that part: If that part is complete [valid time], the duty is established as complete, so one does not fulfill the responsibility by performing it in disliked times. An example is what is said: The end of the time in Fajr is complete, and the time only becomes corrupt by the rising of the sun, which is after the exit of the time; so the obligation is established with the attribute of perfection. Thus, if the sun rises during the prayer, the obligatory prayer becomes void, because he cannot complete the prayer except with the attribute of deficiency due to the time. But if that part was deficient, as in the Asr prayer—for the end of the time is the time of the sun's reddening, and the time then is corrupt—the duty is established with the attribute of deficiency. For this reason, it is necessary to say it is permissible [to pray Asr] then, despite the corruption of the time. The second way is to make every part of the parts of the time a cause, not by way of transfer—for saying that implies invalidating the causality established by the Law—and this does not entail the multiplication of the obligation, for the second part only establishes...

...the essence of what the first part established. This belongs to the category of overlapping causes and the multiplicity of witnesses in the chapter of disputes. The cause of the obligation of Fasting is the witnessing of the month, due to the direction of the address upon witnessing the month and the attribution of fasting to it. The cause of the obligation of Zakat is the ownership of a productive Nisab (minimum taxable amount), essentially or legally. Considering the obligation of the cause, hastening is permissible in the chapter of performance. The cause of the obligation of Hajj is the House [Kaaba], due to its attribution to the House and the non-repetition of the duty in one's lifetime. Based on this, if one performs Hajj before the existence of ability [financial/physical means], it stands in for the Hajj of Islam due to the existence of the cause. In this, it differs from the payment of Zakat before the existence of the Nisab, due to the absence of the cause.

Discussion on Impediments (Mawani') being four. The cause for the obligation of Sadaqat al-Fitr is the person [head] whom one supports and has authority over. Considering the cause, hastening is permissible, such that its performance before the day of Fitr is permissible. The cause for the obligation of Ushr (tithe) is productive land by the reality of the yield. The cause for the obligation of Kharaj (land tax) is land suitable for cultivation, so it is productive legally. The cause for the obligation of Wudu is Prayer according to some; for this reason, Wudu is obligatory on the one upon whom Prayer is obligatory, and there is no Wudu on the one upon whom there is no Prayer. Some said the cause of its obligation is Hadath (impurity), and the obligation of Prayer is a condition; this has been narrated from Muhammad explicitly. The cause for the obligation of Ghusl is menstruation, postpartum bleeding, and sexual impurity (Janabah). Section: The Judge and Imam Abu Zaid said: Impediments are of four divisions: An impediment that prevents the convening of the Effective Cause ('Illah). An impediment that prevents its completion. An impediment that prevents the beginning of the ruling. And an impediment that prevents its continuation.

The parallel of the first: The sale of a free person, carrion, and blood. For the absence of the locus prevents the transaction from convening as an effective cause for providing the ruling. Based on this are all suspensions (Ta'liqat) according to us, for suspension prevents the transaction from convening as an effective cause before the existence of the condition, according to what we mentioned. For this reason, if he swore not to divorce his wife, then suspended the divorce of his wife on entering the house, he does not break the oath. An example of the second: The destruction of the Nisab during the year, the refusal of one of the two witnesses to testify, and the rejection of half the contract. An example of the third: Sale with a condition of option, and the remaining of time regarding the person with an excuse. An example of the fourth: The option of puberty, manumission, and inspection; lack of compatibility; and healing in the chapter of wounds, based on this principle. This is considering the permissibility of specifying the legal effective cause. As for the opinion of those who do not say the specification of the effective cause is permissible, the impediment according to him is of three divisions: An impediment preventing the beginning of the effective cause, an impediment preventing its completion, and an impediment preventing the continuation of the ruling. But upon the completion of the effective cause, the ruling is established inevitably. Based on this, whatever the first group made an impediment to the establishment of the ruling, the second group made it an impediment to the completion of the effective cause.
And upon this principle, the discussion revolves between the two groups.

Discussion explaining the meaning of Fard (Obligatory) linguistically and legally. Section: Fard linguistically is estimation (Taqdir). The 'Mafruḍat' of the Sharia are its estimated measures such that they do not accept increase or decrease. In the Sharia, it is what is established by a definitive proof (Dalil Qat'i) in which there is no doubt. Its ruling is the obligation to act upon it and to believe in it. And Wajib (Necessary) is the 'falling' [or landing], meaning what falls upon the servant without choice from him. It is said it is from 'al-Wajbah,' which is agitation/disturbance. The Wajib is named such because it is agitated between the Fard and the Nafl (Voluntary). So it became Fard regarding action, such that leaving it is not permissible, and Nafl regarding belief, so believing in it decisively is not binding upon us. In the Sharia, it is what is established by a proof in which there is doubt, like an interpreted verse or an authentic solitary report (Ahad). Its ruling is what we mentioned. The Sunnah is an expression for the path followed and pleasing in the chapter of religion, whether it is from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, or from the Companions. He, peace be upon him, said: (Upon you is my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Caliphs after me; bite onto it with your molars).

Its ruling is that a person is demanded to keep it alive and deserves blame for leaving it, unless he leaves it with an excuse. Nafl (Voluntary) is an expression for increase. Booty (Ghanimah) is called Nafl because it is an increase over what is the objective of Jihad. In the Sharia, it is an expression for what is an increase over the Fara'id (Obligatory acts) and Wajibat (Necessary acts). Its ruling is that a person is rewarded for doing it and is not punished for leaving it. Nafl and Tatawwu' are parallels.

Discussion on what 'Azimah (Resolve/Strict Law) is linguistically and legally. Section: 'Azimah is the intent when it is at the utmost firmness. For this reason, we said that the 'resolve' to have intercourse is a 'return' in the chapter of Zihar, because it is like the existent, so it is permissible to consider it existent when the indication stands. For this reason, if he said 'I resolve' [to swear], he becomes a swearer. In the Sharia, it is an expression for the rulings that bind us primarily. It was named 'Azimah because it is at the utmost firmness due to the firmness of its cause, which is that the Commander is obligated to be obeyed by the ruling that He is our God and we are His slaves. The divisions of 'Azimah are what we mentioned of Fard and Wajib.

Discussion explaining Rukhsa (Concession/License) linguistically and legally. As for Rukhsa, it is an expression for ease and facility. In the Sharia, it is diverting the command from difficulty to ease by means of an excuse in the subject (Mukallaf). Its types vary due to the variation of their causes, which are the excuses of the servants. In the outcome, they revert to two types. One of them is the license of action while the prohibition remains, similar to pardon in the chapter of crimes. That is like running a word of disbelief on the tongue with the tranquility of the heart during coercion, reviling the Prophet, peace be upon him, destroying the property of a Muslim, and killing a soul unjustly. Its ruling is that if he was patient until he was killed, he would be rewarded for refraining from the forbidden out of veneration for the prohibition of the Lawgiver, peace be upon him. The second type is changing the attribute of the action such that it becomes permissible (Mubah) in his right. Allah the Exalted said: {But whoever is forced by severe hunger}. That is like coercion to eat carrion and drink wine. Its ruling is that if he refrained from consuming it until he was killed, he would be a sinner for refraining from the permissible, and he becomes like the killer of himself.

Discussion that arguing without proof is of types. Section: Argumentation without proof is of types. Among them: 1 - Reasoning by the absence of the cause for the absence of the ruling. Example: Vomit does not break wudu because it did not exit from the two passages. And a brother does not emancipate [automatically] upon a brother because there is no birth [relationship] between them. Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, was asked: 'Is retaliation (Qisas) obligatory on the partner of a boy [in murder]?' He said: 'No, because the Pen is lifted from the boy.' The questioner said: 'Then it must be obligatory on the partner of the father, because the Pen is not lifted from the father.' So holding onto the absence of the cause for the absence of the ruling became like saying: 'Fulan did not die because he did not fall from the roof.' Unless the cause of the ruling is restricted to a meaning, such that that meaning is necessary for the ruling; then one argues by its negation for the absence of the ruling. An example is what was narrated from Muhammad, may Allah have mercy on him, that he said: 'The offspring of the usurped [animal] is not guaranteed because it is not usurped.' And 'There is no retaliation on the witness in the issue of witnesses to retaliation if they retract, because he is not a killer.' This is because usurpation is necessary for the liability of usurpation, and killing is necessary for the existence of retaliation.

Likewise, holding onto 'Presumption of Continuity' (Istishab al-Hal) is holding onto the absence of proof, since the existence of a thing does not necessitate its remaining. So it is suitable for defense, not for imposition (Ilzam). Based on this, we said: If someone claims slavery against a person of unknown lineage, then commits a crime against him, the indemnity (Arsh) of a free man is not obligatory upon him, because imposing the indemnity of a free man is an imposition, so it is not established without proof. Based on this, we said: If blood exceeds ten [days] in menstruation and the woman has a known habit, she is returned to the days of her habit, and the excess is Istihadah (irregular bleeding). This is because the excess over the habit is connected to the blood of menstruation and the blood of Istihadah, so it bore both possibilities. If we judged by the breaking of the waiting period [ruling it as new menses], we would be acting without proof. Likewise, if she started as a beginner with puberty having Istihadah, her menstruation is ten days, because what is less than ten bears the possibility of menstruation and Istihadah. If we judged by the lifting of menstruation [before ten], we would be acting without proof. This is contrary to what is after ten, due to the existence of proof that menstruation does not exceed ten. Among the proofs that there is no proof in it [Istishab] except as an argument for defense, not imposition, is the issue of the Missing Person (Mafqud). For indeed, no one else is entitled to his inheritance [defense of his ownership], but if one of his relatives dies during his absence, he does not inherit from him [cannot impose ownership]. So the entitlement of another is repelled without proof, but entitlement is not established for him without proof.

Discussion that there is no Khums (one-fifth tax) in Ambergris according to Abu Hanifa. If it is said: It has been narrated from Abu Hanifa, may Allah have mercy on him, that he said: 'There is no Khums in Ambergris because the report (Athar) has not been transmitted regarding it,' and this is holding onto the absence of proof. We said: He only mentioned that to explain his excuse for not saying there is Khums in Ambergris. For this reason, it is narrated that Muhammad asked about Khums in Ambergris. He [Abu Hanifa] said: 'What is the case of Ambergris that there is no Khums in it?' He said: 'Because it is like fish.' He said: 'And what is the case of fish that there is no Khums in it?' He said: 'Because it is like water, and there is no Khums in it.' And Allah the Exalted knows best the truth. Usul al-Shashi is completed with 'Umdat al-Hawashi.
